description:
My friend and I had a huge craving for spaghetti and we remembered this spot from a previous visit. I checked on Yelp for reservations (super convenient btw) and luckily there was availability for the later night. If you don't have a reservation, you may run the risk of having to wait a bit, because it gets crowded on a Friday night . When we arrived, we were a bit early, but when our reservation time came up, we were seated right away.

The ambiance is quirky and the service was great! Our server was attentive and I appreciated her fun and joking energy. Between two of us, we got the following:

- Spaghetti & Meatballs (+1 Extra Meatball = 4 Total)
- Cheesy Garlic Bread
- Mozzarella Cauliflower Balls
- 2 Beers on Draft

The star of the show for me was the spaghetti and meatballs, which was the reason why we came back. I don't think it's meant to be flashy, nor a game changing dish, but it's a dish that provided me with such warmth and comfort to my taste buds and soul. It's like a warm hug being given to your stomach - it's just such a solid plate of spaghetti and meatballs. The meatball was the right texture, not dry or overly seasoned. I'd be curious to try it in the sandwich. The mozzarella cauliflower balls were an unexpected treat, as we tried this for the first time. It's like a friend mac and cheese ball without the mac and my friend who doesn't really seek cauliflower, really enjoyed it. For the cheesy garlic bread, I probably would pass on it next time because the complimentary bread would have been sufficient for the pasta.

We initially intended to order two plates of the spaghetti and meatballs, but luckily pulled back. The whole meal was just right (with the added meatball), leaving us feeling content, if not full. I'll definitely be back to try the other things on the menu!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Wow where do I begin. Came here on a Monday night @ 6pm to be exact. Waited 10mins to be seated. To be told that they were completely booked with reservations. Hold on I thought walk ins was welcome. Well the host suggested other wise telling me and my party of 6 (2 adults and 3kids) we would have to wait 45 minutes or sit at the bar. Words was exchange and another patron stated she never heard of that. When do you need reservations.
Another 15mins went by when the host let us know that someone had cancelled. Yeah right there was never a reservation to begin with. 

Now the waiter she was hella rude maybe because we asked for the free bread twice, and as our party wasn't aware that they don't split checks. When the check came everything was itemize. For instance if you order the spaghetti and meat balls on the menu its a flat rate. However on the receipt they charge the toppings separately.

I never mentioned that this was my first time and been wanting to eat here since they was in that hole in the wall across from Pizza Hut, yeah. Take that Ms. I'VE BEEN WORKING HERE FOR 5 YEARS. Her attitude sucked. The bartender rocks and has great customer service.

As we proceeded to leave the table the host rudely came over and stated that not tipping affect all of them. Look I work for tips and tips are given on good customer service and that I didn't receive from the beginning. Now because you decided to seat us and take our order that's your job. However being rude with gestures, facial expressions, and sighs don't get you jack.

Beware!!! I won't be going back and will share my experience with others that want to dine with them. Its really sad too because the food was actually good.
author: Charlotte T.

description:
Have eaten here twice now and enjoyed both times. The spaghetti w/meatballs is definitely good, though it's not much different than what you could make at home. My suggestion is to try out their more interesting dishes such as one that features habanero peppers and another with mussels/clams. I've also had good luck with their specials. Steak with potatoes and asparagus was ok.

Diverse drink options (including a couple cheap beers), eclectic vibe, and very friendly service. A perfect place to get together with friends and just eat and have fun--reminds me of getting pizza with the team after sports games in school (but with much better food). Will definitely be coming back here!
author: Matt A.

description: I came here yesterday and ordered spaghetti and meatballs and some garlic bread. Overall, pretty mediocre experience. I thought the garlic bread wasn't anything special and it certainly needed some finishing salt. While the meatballs were well cooked (i.e. not overcooked), they similarly, lacked some salt. For over $20, I was honestly expecting a lot more. Nothing in particular stood out for either the spaghetti or the sauce - definitely something I could've cooked at home with a jar of sauce.
author: Austin W.

description: Always a great time at Emmy's! Came in randomly and Alex (he's the BEST!) hooked us up with a booth that we can people watch in  Ordered prawn ceviche, fried mozzarella balls and two orders of spaghetti and meatballs! PRO TIP: ONE ORDER OF SPAGHETTI IS ENOUGH FOR TWO! Will definitely come back for Alex's hospitality!
author: Attiana P.

description:
A coworker was nice enough to share some of her lunch. Our delivery order arrived via Caviar on Friday, July 13th around 12:30pm.

*Spaghetti Special + House Bread (Lunch): Emmy's Famous Spaghetti and Marina sauce, Includes house bread and spaghetti with red sauce ($12), Spaghetti and Meatballs: 2 Meatballs (+$4)
*French Fries ($6)

I had toyed with ordering something from here as well, but they didn't really offer much through Caviar. Just spaghetti, bread, salad, and fries. All other dishes just said avail later. So note there's not much selection if you order lunch for delivery through Caviar.

My coworker who got the spaghetti loved it. Especially the meatballs. She said they rivalled a spot we frequently order from where they actually specialize in meatballs. I tried some of the fries and they were fine. Thicker than I like so very potato-y. I tend to prefer thinner fries as I like my fries crispy. These were kind of limp and soggy. The delivery time probably didn't help, but they also didn't have the nice golden fried color. If you have a fry craving, I don't think these would fulfill that.

Solid spaghetti and meatballs, but I wish they offered more variety on their lunch delivery menu. It seems like you have more options when placing a takeout order. So why not offer the same options for delivery as well? Seems kinda weird to me.
author: Elena N.

description:
Excellent pasta at a solid price point to match the reasonable portion sizes. I ordered the Buccatini Alfredo ($17), which was very creamy! I usually like a lot of sauce packed on my pasta, so this worked for me. I just had to add a bit of salt to taste as it was heavier on the creamy side, and needed just a tad more of savoriness. My fiance order the spaghetti ($17), and he most enjoyed the meatballs! Not sure what kind of meat is in it, but he enjoyed it! I love thick pasta noodles that are filled with carbs (lol), so I'm a fan. 

For cocktails, we ordered the Lychee Margarita and the Matcha Panacea. I wouldn't be dying to come back for the drinks as they weren't anything special.  

The ambiance is casual and fun. It's a good place to go if meeting up with a couple people. There didn't seem to be a lot of tables for large parties, although there was one large family seated at the corner tables so it's possible I'm sure. The menu is very disorganized (although it has character), so it was hard for me to easily find certain categories. 

Our waitress was personable, relaxed, and had a good sense of humor (without being over the top)!
author: Jazzica D.

description:
It may look like a typical dive bar in the Mission, but the pasta at Emmy's makes this place perfect for a casual, no frills, dinner date.

Came here with my fiancée on a Friday night on a last minute reservation we made the night before. We were looking to get our pasta fix, but didn't want a place over-the-top fancy.

My fiancée ordered the Bucatini Alfredo and I was in the mood for a classic Spaghetti & Meatballs. For the price of $17 each, these dishes were worth it based on taste and serving size (and location). I enjoyed the tender, juicy meatballs in my dish, but the pasta was just plain to me. What was more memorable to me was the taste of my fiancée's dish, as it was the perfect amount of creamy and cheesy. (I'll probably be getting her dish next time!)

The cocktails were okay. I'd probably just get wine next time. We tried the old-fashioned donut for dessert which was good, but basic. The service was as chill and welcoming as the ambiance.

Overall, I would definitely return to Emmy's when my next pasta craving rolls around, and I want a place that I know won't disappoint or try too hard.
author: Ryan M.

description:
This restaurant is awesome and it's always nice to have a spaghetti place nearby.

I suddenly had a craving for Spaghetti with Meatballs and stumbled upon this restaurant while walking.

I came in and took a look at the menu, then placed an order for Spaghetti with Meatballs and a side of French Fries. That bowl of spaghetti is delicious with the sauce. The meatballs I had requested to add in is so good, the meat is tender and juicy. Plus the French Fries were fried to a perfect crispy texture. This is truly a wonderful and delicious meal. Very simple and the portion sizes are good enough to keep me filled for the afternoon. This is certainly the best lunch meal I have had.

If dining with a large group (10 or more) making a reservation is highly recommended.

The food is delicious, friendly staff and good service. Overall, positive experience here.
author: Bennett W.

description: What hip trendy place. This is a true Mission district type of restaurant. The service was great. The waitress was super upbeat, friendly and helpful. They were quick. Period. Now...I'm definitely into "girly" drinks...so I had a couple fruit cocktails. Both were great. Not overly strong. Now...the spaghetti...it was wonderful!! The meatballs were huge and full of flavor as well...I'll be back!!!
author: Olive R.

description:
This place was one of the few restaurants open in SF on a late night. We happened upon Emmys because we were starving!! This place didn't disappoint! 
They have more of a bar vibe going on. Dark and a little loud. So not a great place to take young kids. It was mainly young adults here. 
We had their garlic bread, chicken Alfredo pasta and spaghetti and meatballs. It hit the spot! The sauces were thick and creamy, rich in flavor. The portions were large and generous that I took my leftovers home for another meal.
author: Andrea K.

description:
This place is a goddamn institution of La Lengua. Emmy's strikes a nice balance for the neighborhood: it's hip, but not too cool for school; it keeps it simple, but is far from boring; and its prices/portions are just right.

Getting the s'ghetti and meatballs on your first go is the obvious choice, but everything here is pretty good. Be sure to bring your appetite and appreciation for unicorn murals.
author: M G.

description:
I had seen this restaurant on my way to Bernal Heights Hill and it looked so cool and fun.  

I wasn't disappointed when I came.  Emmy's is happening and bustling.  I'd recommend making a reservation for Fri or Sat.  This doesn't seem like a reservationy place but it gets busy AF so it's just better so you don't have to wait around.  

I heard that they had zoodles which I had wanted to try forever.  They were filling and loaded with fresh basil and tomatoes.  I love pasta so I was excited for this but I didn't get the same tired lethargic feeling after a big meal of pasta.  The peanut butter bar is also a great choice for dessert.

Emmy's is quite social and exudes a lot of retro sassy character.  It can be used as a starting off place for the many bars in the area or just a night out in itself.
author: Joan W.

description: MMMMM YUMMY! I love all kinds of pasta and Emmy's spaghetti shack did not disappoint. I ordered the spaghetti with meatballs and my boyfriend ordered the buccatini alfredo! Both were very good and hit the spot. I also LOVED their bread along with the vinegar. The ambiance is quirky and the waitresses are very energetic!!
author: Mauricia L.

description: Meatballs were the most amazing thing I've had in a while. Portions are awesome and atmosphere great.  Didn't really feel all that kid friendly when I first got there (there's a bar vibe a bit) but overall it was fine to bring my 5 and 9 yr olds.
author: Neal D.

description:
This is one of the most unique Italian restaurants I've been to. The moment you walk in you are bombarded by a cacophony of different images and styles. A truly unique and interesting location. 

The spaghetti and meatballs was probably the best dish I had there. The sangria is a must according to my friends. The zucchini zodos were pleasant but nothing to phone home about. The linguine was good. 

The Focaccia was very good but I was disappointed to see that you can't get a second serving. If I remember correctly we were encouraged to get garlic bread instead. 

The customer service was a little odd, it was both helpful and nice but at times I felt a bit aggressive. Maybe I'm just being sensitive but at times it felt a bit cold. 

Overall, it's definitely a place worth checking out if you've never been. But I doubt I'll be returning.
author: Juan Carlos H.

description:
The place has a couple larger tables, so if you're going with a group on the weekend, make a reservation! There's a fee if you make a reservation and don't show up, but if you're sure you're going, that'll help.

When we arrived, the place was quite busy, with a few people waiting inside for a table. Since we had a reservation, we didn't have to wait long and were seated within a few minutes.

For food, I tried the spaghetti with three meatballs and the zoodles. I was a fan of the meatballs. I liked that they had capers in them and were flavorful. The spaghetti itself was fine though a bit on the sweet side.. I wasn't the biggest fan of the zoodles. The pesto was a bit too sweet for me. However, when I mixed some of the spaghetti and meatballs into it, the flavors worked well together and balanced out. The portions are on the larger side. I was able to split the two dishes with two friends, and we were all full by the end.

For drinks, I tried the white sangria. SO GOOD. Also a fan of the fruit selection (strawberry, peach, orange).

We didn't really interact with many staff members, but our host was super friendly and personable, which I appreciated.

The menu is a bit busy/hard to read at first. Something I didn't realize until paying the bill is that there's a 3.5% fee if you pay with a card, but that didn't bug me too much, and overall, I had a solid experience here.
author: Jennifer W.

description: This place is awesome! Vegan meatballs are spot on-delish. Pasta sauce was good & very large portions. The ceviche was excellent.  The chocolate cake was good (they make it there), but VERY rich and almost too dry. Overall experience was pleasant and the inside is pretty neat to look at.
author: Rob M.

description:
I hope to come back and flesh out my experience of Emmy's, but I visited for the first time last weekend and had one of the best entrees I have ever had anywhere in my nearly 70 years: the Mayan Prawn Risotto. Three flavors predominate: garlic, lemon, and hot peppers. None of them backs down and somehow together they achieve a perfect balance for the silky risotto and the lovingly infused prawns. It was impossible to take my last bite until there were no bites left to take. I suspect the presence of lemon oil, due to the wonderful intensity of the lemon flavor (meant to ask the server but forgot!) My server did say after I ordered that it was her personal favorite as well.

My wife had the spaghetti and meatballs and waxed enthusiastic about the meatballs in particular: I had a taste and found them imaginatively flavored and textured, tho I was so immersed in my prawn experience that I was reluctant to let anything interrupt it for long. Our vegan son had the spaghetti marinara, I think, and was very happy with his entree too.

We lived in SF from the early seventies thru 1999, including years in the Mission near 24th Street, and now return as tourists from Fairfield several times a year. Our son moved back to SF to a neighborhood in the Haight, close to the Panhandle. It was he who suggested Emmy's, which we had never heard of. I look forward to return visits and to being able to provide a more nuanced review, but I was so bowled over by this one dish that I had to put my two cents in!
author: TIm D.

description:
Cute little spot in Bernal with great vibes and delicious food! 

We got the cheesy garlic bread which had the perfect amount of cheese that was actually melting on top of the bread. We also shared a spaghetti meatballs but the vegan version! It was so good! 

Hung out here for a while after some happy hour drinks at El Rio. Maybe next time I'll just get drinks here.
author: Soundarya C.

description:
Meh, it's nothing special at all. I can easily make this at home. I think this place is popular because it relatively cheap and survived in SF for a long time.

Skip it and go to any of the other SF pasta joints instead. Beretta, Tosca, Cotogna, A16-there are tons. Not worth the money. The service and people are super nice, I'll give them that.
author: Prakash N.

description:
Emmy's. Spaghetti. Shack. 

I was intrigued by the name alone. We arrived to a rather eclectic Italian restaurant, unlike any I've stepped inside before. The playlist was on point. The decor was funky. Emmy's mirrored the dive bar of Italian restaurants.

Holla holla shot calla to Yelp reservations for making our booking a breeze! When we arrived, the server crammed the eight of us into the corner table by the window. It was tight, but the ambiance worked. Sangria and wine were prevalent on the menu, but I was pleased to discover a 22 oz. bomber of a double IPA from Green Flash Brewing. Score!

Cheesy Garlic Bread hit the table. In seconds, it disappeared. It was scrumptious, but a very American take on garlic bread, which wasn't completely my style. The main meal of Linguine was also very good. A light sauce, big chunks of chorizo, and clams and mussels scattered the plate. The mussels were tiny and disappointing. Overall, the dish was a big pile of comforting pasta.

I'd like to think Emmy's is all thrill, no frill. The menu is concise, which I adore. However, often when menus are constrictive my expectations increase. All in all, our experience here was great. The waitress did a fantastic job of taking care of our large party. That's worth raising a glass to!
author: Matthew C.

description:
This place is cool. I liked the vibe. The food and service was good too. They hand out bread with olive oil + balsamic vinegar when you first sit down. We ordered the ceviche prawns as an appetizer. It was fantastic except it didn't come with enough nachos to scoop all the food up. We had to keep requesting bread and nacho chips. "Just add some more nacho chips, they are so inexpensive." was the first thing I said after leaving. 

The pork chop and potatoes tasted really good. I thought it was a bit too expensive for the portion sizes but I would still go back to eat again. Also a good spot for a dinner date.
author: Philip D.

description: Came here around 8:45 on a Thursday night. The place was busy but we were able to get a booth table right away. The staff seemed playful and welcoming. I ordered the Mayan Prawn Risotto and my vegan friend got the Zoodles aka zucchini noodles with vegan pesto and vegan meatballs. Next time we will pass of the vegan meatlessballs but the pesto was amazing. The house wine was sooo good too! This place has a chill atmosphere and you get free bread and oil/basalmic which is delish too!
author: Julianne O.

description:
If you're like me and all you want in the world is a good dish of spaghetti and meatballs, come here. Their meatballs are 8/10! (If they were a lot bigger than they already are, I would bump up that rating more). Sauce was good, not too sour or watery. They skimp on the cheese a bit though.

Bf and I also got some garlic bread for a starter and that was also very good. We got it without cheese, but I'm sure it's like 200x more delicious with it.

We also got the linguine. The mussels and clams were cooked perfectly, but everything else about it was ...meh :( It was super watery, like they forgot to drain the pasta water. Sure, the liquid was good and flavorful, but I didn't ask for a seafood noodle soup.

It is pretty loud in there, so it may not be the best first date spot, unless you're okay sitting side by side. Service was good though and the place is fun!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
A shack it is not. A simple SF restaurant, it is.

With a name like "shack" in the title, you probably need to understand that they're not going to blow you away with fine dining. They probably don't have white linens on the tables nor "thank you, madam's" running around in the air. No, it's a simple spot just trying to keep it low-key. I mean, that's a lot their thing, and only a little their schtick. But I'm into it. 

We arrived in a large-ish group, having made arrangements via Yelp Reservations beforehand. We sat near the front window, which alcoves just a bit and made me wonder if this used to be some kind of retail establishment at some point in its history? We were the window display, but the pasta is the product.

When you don't know what to get, you go with what's in the title. The place is a spaghetti shack, so you probably get the spaghetti. That was my thought process and it worked out swell. The big ol' meatballs in the spaghetti and meatballs dish were hearty, well-seasoned, and enough food to fill me. The noodles were cooked well and the sauce wasn't overbearing or over-portioned. Again, if you have spaghetti in the title, you should nail it. They did.

There are other menu items, other pastas, and we also got a load of cheese bread which was, you know, cheese on bread. Choose from the wines on the menu, kept simple, and you're out the door for a reasonable price. 

I really like places like this. They have limits, of course. If you're not in the mood for something on their limited menu, you probably end up elsewhere. But specialty restaurants, especially those that don't take themselves too seriously, are a great find when they get it right. I think Emmy is getting it right.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Emmy's food is simply just excellent! I relocated to Nevada and whenever I'm in SF my husband and I always come back. 

The staff is friendly and accommodating - great vibe and decor too. 

Emmy has special items she adds to the menus (fun adds seasonally too with the change of veggies). The cocktail list is always delicious and definitely a legit wine list. 

Two must haves - the garlic cheese bread and the spaghetti and meatballs! 

Now if only I could get her to open one in Vegas....
author: Alis D.

description:
This place is great, but make reservations as it gets busy! 
The pasta dishes are all good! 
Very unique menu design
A little dark but perfect for a date or even small group meet ups !
author: Jad A.

description:
Emmy's is just average. 

My boyfriend and I split a caesar salad and the spaghetti and meatballs. It was ok. The portions are large, so it's definitely a good idea to split things. I noticed both of the tables next to us ordered spaghetti and meatballs individually, and couldn't finish their plates.

The caesar salad was 80% lettuce 19% dressing and 1% croutons. Why!? Why skimp on the croutons!? The salad was drowning in dressing, making it feel more on the unhealthy side.

The spaghetti and meatballs were good, though I did start wondering "Why am I paying $16 for this when i could make it at home?" Definitely not mindblowing.

That said, Emmy's has a kitschy charm that's unique and feels refreshing compared to all the other bougie, hipster joints around town. Just don't expect the food to knock your pants off.
author: Fiona F.

description:
Spaghetti is never my first choice when it comes to dinner but after having Emmy's meatballs, I may have to think otherwise moving forward.

It never really matters to me what I'm doing so long as I'm with the right people. When the latter is in place, a good time is guaranteed. On Monday last week, I had the pleasure of eating dinner with seven of my Yelp colleagues. We got to spend some time getting to know each other and enjoying some great conversation. Another plus was that not everyone in the group has the same appetite as me so I lucked out in craving both Emmy's meatballs and her eggplant parmesan. I ordered the eggplant parmesan and was able to finish up my friend's meatball dish. Winning on two fronts.

We started off with their bread and oil and vinegar. We ordered the garlic cheese bread but I really wasn't a fan. I certainly would recommend the meatballs. Big balls, juicy, tender, and delicious. Each ball can be broken down into 5 or 6 bites. The eggplant parmesan was delicious, too. My picture doesn't do much justice nor does it show how big the dish is actually is.

Service was on point. Our waitress was fun and bubbly and was very attentive to the group.

So glad I was able to try all that I wanted from their menu!
author: Xerxes N.

description: I love this place: great service and not over the top, food is always good, and a warm donut for dessert. It's a regular on our list of favorites!
author: Alaina N.

description:
Lovedd the speghetti and meatballs and looooved the white asiago cream pasta (forgot the name) !! 
Don't forget the garlic bread!
author: Hye-Jin O.

description: Love it! Can't go wrong with the spaghetti and meatballs. A cute place to dinner with friends or a chill date night. Service is always on point and food is flavorful. For pasta, it's a bit of a splurge, but nothing out of the ordinary for SF prices.
author: Christy C.

description: The Spaghetti  and meat balls was delicious with many variety of flavors. The garlic bread was yummy.
author: Juan V.

description:
I was meeting up with friends on a Friday evening. Starting with the food: I ordered the house spaghetti. It was a surprisingly huge helping, and it was pretty good. The sauce was a little sweet, but otherwise it was well worth the price. The garlic bread appetizer was good, too. There were eight of us, and everyone seemed to enjoy their meals.

Now, the bad part: Assuming it would be hectic, I made reservations online through their website more than a week in advance (on a Thursday). I received a confirmation email for the correct date. The next evening (a Friday, but a week before the reservation), I received a set of calls and text messages asking where my group was and when we'd be arriving, and then if we were still coming. The next day, I called to confirm the correct reservation date--they had no record of the mix-up or of contacting me multiple times. They confirmed my upcoming reservation.

Fast-forward to the day of the reservation. That afternoon, I received another confirmation email for the correct time. A couple of hours later I receive a couple of texts messages: the first one asked if we could change our reservation time and arrive earlier. I replied and said we would try, but we had several people coming from outside the city. Their reply: "Ok thank you! We will try our best as well." Three hours later, I received a follow-up text: we were on the waiting list. Even though we had made the reservation eight days before and confirmed multiple times.

So, that didn't exactly get things started on the right foot. The food and service were fine, but they didn't make up for the pre-dinner treatment. But the place has character, and the menu design is unique, I guess?
author: Matt C.

description:
My idea of a Cali-Snazzy SF icon. I adore the spaghetti and meatballs, wifey cannot get enough eggplant parmagiana. We both love the cauliflower cheese balls--that's how mozzarella should be done y'all.

The bottle of Tempranillo is a good value and pairs really well with our meals. 

Really upbeat wait staff. Whacky decor. Cool tech in the reservation system. 

This section of Mission St. is horrible for dropping off or picking up an Uber. Make sure you pin a side-street. 

Pricing and portion size is appropriate for a family style sharing. 10 minute walk to Mission Pie for dessert :D
author: Lu-Shien T.

description:
Found this place on yelp. Finally was able to make it here. First of all the parking sucks.  I parked at the BofA next door. After hours is the best time to park here.I was greeted immediately and sat down at a table. The server was attentive as well as the other staff members. I ordered  the famous spaghetti and meatballs . Very very delish. So flavorful and hot . They have a nice variety of beer and wines.I order a Modelo beer . It comes cold in a glass. (Didn't know they serve alcohol).They have a wide variety menu. So much to chose from.Well worth the effort to come here. Nice vibe. Come here and you won't be disappointed...
Cheers
author: Eric A.

description: Such a family staple in our house. It's perfect for my kids and my parents too. Portions are a good size and the ambiance is fun. My kids love the house specialty of spaghetti and meatballs. The staff are quick on their feet and always helpful.
author: joanna c.

description:
I've been waiting waaaaay too long to write this review, because Emmy's is my absolute favorite restaurant in all of SF and I know that I won't be able to do it justice in a single review -- but I can't put it off any longer!

First things first: you go for the spaghetti and meatballs. And for the fun. You don't go to Emmy's and order a fettuccini alfredo for your entree. That's a rookie mistake. Their starter salads are always excellent, as is their cheesy garlic bread. The cocktails are seasonal, creative, and strong. The carafes of house red wine are very well-priced and very delicious.

The atmosphere is as good as the food -- and that's saying a lot. I always ask everyone I've gone to dinner there with to try to articulate the vibe, and everyone comes up with something different. My best attempt at describing it is -- mom's home cooked spaghetti and meatballs, but mom is a badass Rosie the Riveter with bicep tattoos and eyebrow piercings, and she's gonna serve you your spaghetti and meatballs and you're gonna f***ing like it. Because it's delicious and hearty and good for the soul. And the decor, the decor I can only describe -- with a completely straight face -- as postmodern second wave feminism on acid.

The waitresses are amazing, kind, memorable, and fun. There's a photo booth in the back which is always a great way to remember a particularly exuberant night.

Emmy's has been, and always will be, my favorite restaurant in SF. Great for date night, great for friend groups, great for family outings, great for everything! Keep at it!!
author: Daniel F.

description:
Funny thing, I've never heard of this magical place, since moving to SF 3 years ago, however, once I heard about, that's all I hear now...Emmy's this and Emmy's that. Maybe folks were telling me about this place for years and my selective hearing blocked it out. Anywho, on a cool date night, we decided on this place for it's cool vibe and good food. This was told to me by my date. I had no idea how great it was...

Living in my "bubble" between work and home, I've never really ventured out to outer mission as much so when I arrived here, I thought man, this is far! LOL. From the moment you approach the outside, you know it's going to be an eclectic place. The details in the place really give it personality. From the lights to the tin roof bar to the aprons hanging on the clothes line. Then there's the menu. What a really cool menu! Yes, it's busy but love the colors and personality. It really reflects what a cool place this is. Our server was really helpful and chill. She checked in on us often and gave us our space when needed. 

For dinner, we started with the Shack Caesar salad for $10 and added anchovies for $1. Whole romaine leaves, creamy dressing and fresh parmesan. I love salads that come pretty whole, like an iceberg wedge salad, ones that require a fork and knife. Nothing out of the ordinary as far as flavor, I liked the salad. I really like the option of anchovies which brought a great salty element to the overall bite. For my meal, I got the Linguine for $17. This dish was filled with mussels, clams, Spanish chorizo in an herb butter garlic and white wine sauce. OH EM GEE! I couldn't see the noodles! There were so many mussels, clams and chorizo! I'm only kidding but man it was packed with flavor and the dish was huge. I highly recommend this dish if you're into seafood. 

I'm gonna say it again, what a great spot for a date night! It had such a great vibe, awesome food and great service. This is one of those SF gems that people will always remember when visiting or giving out recommendations. If you're in the area (or even if you're not), make your way to this joint. You will NOT be disappointed!
author: Rockne H.

description: Literally the best spaghetti I've had in the city. Cute atmosphere. Great service. Definitely a mission district destination.
author: Erika S.

description:
When I'm craving carbs, nothing does it for me like a delicious bowl of pasta and bread. 

Emmy's has a menu that looks like it was drawn in colored pencils by a cool kid and the dishes are an assortment of classic flavors for comfort and exotic flavors for the adventurous palette. 

On your first visit, order the spaghetti and meatballs- you get about 2 or 3 huge, tasty meatballs. (Can be ordered a-la-carte) 

On your second visit, order the mayan shrimp risotto. Spicy, tangy, creamy, and so yummy! 

Fun cocktails are available in generous sizes. 
Photo booth and vintage arcade in the back to match the interesting decor.
author: Mitzi G.

description:
I wanted​ to love this place - 
While the atmosphere is casual hipster chic with a touch of an urban Interpretation of counterculture mixed in. It clearly speaks to the changing mission street culture, young, white, "trying to hard to be in" 25 - 35-year-olds.  The menu reflects a mashup of dishes heavy on Italian inspiration with some extras tossed in for excitement. A few things to know if you are planning your first visit; Parking isn't the easiest in that part of the Mission - so plan accordingly. You will need reservations. If you are sensitive to noise levels - bring earplugs and opt out. The high ceilings and poor sound meant for a very loud dinner, more so when the wait staff has to talk over the noise to reach you.
The food options are diverse and eclectic, both the traditional spaghetti and meatballs were filling, but the sauce wasn't the best seasoned (somewhat reminded me of "sauce for non-Italia​ns"). I prefer mine with more depth, however, the Spaghetti Puttanesca had great flavor and didn't overdo the olives to the extent that it was off-putting. Now I will admit, I am a meatball snob and try as I might, don't consider baked meatballs really a "meatball" just simply seasoned ground meat balls,  I come from the "fry them in a cast iron skillet". At our table of 6 all commented on them, and while they were tasty; the "mush" factor from them being overworked in preparation was evident. I had the meatball sandwich, which needed at least one if not two more meatballs to be balanced with the bread as they smashed so much. On a "must try" is the coconut mussels. Truly well done and along with the prawn ceviche and the puttanesca were the meal highlights. By the way - the menu tries hard to be "fun" and "eclectic" to match the vibe of the place, but it mostly is just a mess if you as vision limited. All and all, it can be a fun night out of drinking and eating with the right group of friends - but not a date or night where talking is part of your meal.
author: Frank S.

description:
The service we received last night from Nikki R. boosted my previous 4 star rating to 5 stars.  She is a superstar.  I used to work in customer service, specifically serving tables for a little while, and Nikki did the kinds of things that I would have done.  She went above and beyond with every tiny detail - from finding us the perfect ice bucket for our bottle of wine, to humoring our at-times-fussy toddler, to bringing a special little dish of sliced strawberries for said birthday-girl-toddler, to offering to sneak up on us to catch a candid photo of said photo-hating-birthday-girl-toddler.  

The cauliflower cheese balls were fantastic, served with both a delicious Bolognese and a dill-heavy ranch that knocked our socks off.  The leek and mushroom buccatini couldn't have been better and the seafood linguini packed a spicy punch with fresh Spanish chorizo slices.  After we finished our bottle of wine, we went for a mini carafe of the house red, which amounted to two GENEROUS glasses, for just $12!  They took a reservation for just 3 of us and kids eat free before 7PM!  This is definitely going to be our new Monday night spot.  I would saddle up to a dumpster in the TL for Top Ramen as long as Nikki was serving my table.
author: Emma H.

description: Emmys! Why did I wait so long to try you?! Been living in Bernal for 3 years - finally tried this spot Sunday evening. The interior reminds me partially of a restaurant I loved back in my NYC days (Yaffa Cafe). Staff was fun and friendly - Started with the fried mozzarella cauliflower balls - unique take on a fried starter. Would definitely get that again. Menu offered a nice variety aside from classic pasta dishes. Grabbed a Trumer pils (yay draft!), some grilled chicken alfredo and it was *chef kiss* a perfect fun date dinner.
author: Michael M.

description:
It was my super preferred spaghetti place when it was still in the shack.... but it still is again now... no discussion!!!

Great super nice service in a shack extension style ambience... noice!!

Spaghetti... great cook and quality with the incredibly good meatballs !!! That is what I came for and I will coming for again!!!!

Good strong Italian wine and you get happy to dessert time..... another fav of mines!!!

Peanut butter bar witch chocolate covered from Mitchel's vanilla ice cream !!!!!   Yessss

Ohhh, and remember to book, can do it easily using yelp.


Go gurls!!
author: Gianguido G.

description: I give this a 5 because it's a place you have to try when you're in SF. Walk ins are fine but save yourself from hunger pangs and book a table online. Must order the meatball and the Ceasar salad ... not the most innovative dish but for sure you'd want more.
author: E U.

description:
This is a unique Italian spot with some trendy charm to it. The service was a bit slow but they were busy as well. 

Highlights: Garlic bread is delicious. I do wish it were more toasted and less raw garlic on top though. The mushroom and leek buccatini pasta was pretty good. Fettuccine Alfredo with chicken was delicious! My sister liked the rib with polenta. My mother enjoyed her spaghetti and meatballs plate.

Lowlights: Bread was just ok. I got the Apple and greens salad which was honestly not very good. The blue cheese and vinaigrette overpowered the dish making out hard to finish. 

Overall, still a great spot to hang out and enjoy good food if you order the right dish. They also have a fun mini arcade and photo booth in back.
author: Jacqui C.

description:
I wouldn't come here expecting pasta that's above par by SF standards -- it's very much homecooked greasy spoon diner pasta -- but I think the homey, friendly weird DYI vibes of this place and the generous food/drink portions still make this a fun off-night hang.

I've had the linguini with mussels/clams twice. Both times, the flavoring sauce was watery, the pasta limp, and half the mussels were dead/closed.

The spaghetti and meatball likewise was towering pile of limpness, with what appears to be string cheese slathered on.

Still, we got very drunk and had a blast. The people here are so friendly and have so much heart that I kind of can ignore the flaws in the food.
author: Ken H.

description:
Why 4 stars? Because I enjoyed my meal but would have liked a menu with more variety.

   ---   ---   ---

With a hat tip to Abby S for doing the food research, she found Emmy's who happened to take Yelp Reservations. Italian cuisine + Yelp Reservations = no need to continue searching.

We had a group of 8, and were sat at the round table near the door, with a 2-top added to the end, which worked perfectly.

Upon receiving the menu, I felt like the menu variety was a bit underwhelming. I recently visited Italy and loved ordering prosciutto and mozarella, but nothing like that was on the menu. There were only a few options of wine available, and a small list of pasta dishes. With all that being said, I appreciate that this is a small restaurant and that they would probably rather focus on perfecting a small list of items, rather than not being able to give it their all on ton of different things. For all the talk about the small menu, it's definitely the most unique menu from a visual standpoint. 

I ordered the linguine and thought it was solid. We ordered the garlic cheese bread as an appetizer and I loved every bite of that. Would I visit again? I'd probably sooner check out another Italian spot in SF, but I definitely didn't dislike Emmy's.
author: Brett N.

description:
Cool spot ! Their pasta was so good and it was worth the price and wait. 

Giving it a three stars because the server that helped us gave us a really terrible vibe. It seems like she doesn't even want to help us. Rarely checks up on us and when she does, it seems like we were all an inconvenience.

We did hve a great time overall but we feel really rushed even after eating. 

I guess you should just expect the unexpected.
author: Adrian P.

description:
I've been wanting to try Emmy's Spaghetti Shack for some time now. Ever since I walked past it on this fascinating strip of Mission south of 24th (I've also wanted to try the Sushi place and Peruvian place - seriously one of the best hidden gems for food in the City).

Due to the storm causing a tree to fall on a Bart train, I knew I would be ejected onto 24th Street station and figured I would take the quick walk from there. What I didn't realize was the rain was coming down torrential and sideways so by the time I got to Emmy's I was completely soaked. Fortunately the staff is incredibly nice (one of the things that makes it 5 star in my opinion) and got me seated at the bar and were quickly attentive even if I wanted to spend some time looking over.

As I opened the menu I got the complimentary focaccia with oil and vinegar and quickly went to the drinks - hey, I was soaked externally so might as well get soaked internally. At this point a few others with my idea came in and the staff realized how bad it had been down the road.

To start, I got the Pear Shack Mule. I had been debating wines, but as I didn't know what I was going to order figure booze would be a solid first round. I love mules, I love pear - had to order it. It was delicious, you get tasty pear, not too strong and made me forget a bit that I was just as covered in liquid. Star for this!

But I came for food, too! The cheesy garlic bread were a must, but I had trouble deciding between Emmy's Famous Spaghetti and Meatballs, or the Linguine with mussels, clams, and chorizo. On one hand, it is the signature dish; on the other hand, I love a garlicy linguine and clams. I brought this up to the bartender and she wanted to push me to the spaghetti but also brought in other staff and her friends for their input. One of her friend's husband has only ever ordered the spaghetti for the 15 years this place has been open and that solidified it.

The cheesy garlic bread was okay. Garlicky Texas toast topped with cheese. Moses' Beard I miss good, greasy garlic knots. This was the lowest point of the meal - aside from being soaked.

The Spaghetti quickly made up for it as the steaming plate of noodles and 3 meatballs covered in cheese appeared before me. Perfectly cooked, the sauce didn't need anything either, and while not the best meatballs I've had, they were good. Tried to get as many forkfuls of spaghetti, meatball, and garlic bread as I could. A star for the food!

I also ordered a second Pear Shack Mule around this time.

Now to cap out the 5 star rating: music and ambiance. The music was an 80s Pandora playlist, guessing David Bowie (RIP) but with a good mix of Talking Heads, Tears for Fears, and other great pop tracks. I LOVE this music and have my own 80s mix. As well, the decorations in the shack are delightful - between the futuristic horses running through a waterfall rainbow, the hanging pantaloons, the photo booth, and funny signs. Just coming here to look around is worth it. 

Again, have to get back to the staff. All of them were hard working and great. Even though the bartender was talking with her friends likewise trapped by the weather, she was attentive to me and the other bar patrons. She even apologized for talking with "the family" but I thought she was great and tipped justly. 

I would gladly return for to try that linguine and experience more of the Shack. Preferably dry this time.
author: Michael C.

description:
I came here on a Saturday night, at a later hour for dinner, but not right before they closed, so they weren't too busy. 

This is a great place to go for a later comfort food dinner place. I like that they have zoodles (carb free) option. But I wanted all the carbs. Spaghetti and meatballs was my choice. And it was a large plate, so I had some left overs, and they heated up great! 

Also, the SANGRIA. The red sangria was a nice refreshing compliment to my pasta. I could have ordered a few more during dinner, but I was displaying some self restraint (I don't really know why I did that). 

This place is definitely on my radar for later evening comfort food.
author: Vicky L.

description: Well worth the trip out to Bernal. My new favorite spot. Staff was hella nice and I really enjoyed our food.
author: James D.

description: My favorite place to take people visiting from out of town, or for a casual birthday/celebration dinner. I love the habanero risotto and the spaghetti and meatballs!!
author: Shizuka L.

description:
Do you see that crowd of hungry peeps waiting outside the restaurant, yearning to get inside and get a taste of some of the best spaghetti in SF? You should be one of those people. 

Emmy's Spaghetti Shack is a brand new fav for me. It's a cute spot in the Mission with unique decorations, friendly service, and amazing food. There's also a bar so you can have a drink (or two) while you wait. 

Luckily, we had reservations for Saturday night at 7:45pm (still had to end up waiting about 15-20 mins for a table to clear). So yes, make reservations if you can. The host was friendly and patient, as the restaurant was bursting at the seams. Our server was friendly and engaging was well, so 5 stars for service! 

We ordered the famous spaghetti and meatballs, and my god the portions are huge! I only had a salad all day before coming here, so best believe I was starving. Ended up not being able to finish it, so had to take some home (anyone else love leftover spaghetti?). Three huge meatballs come on a blanket of spaghetti doused with flavorful sauce, topped with parmesan cheese flakes. 

Great food, atmosphere, and service. Can't wait to be back!!
author: Danny C.

description:
Finally popped in here, and on a random Saturday, the wait was only 15 minutes in the evening.

We started with the cheesy garlic bread, and that was a great start to the dairy celebration.

The orecchiette with brocolli rabe was probably my favorite. Oh so creamy, and the bitter veggies helped balance out the fat bomb a little.

The spaghetti and meatballs was of course solid, though the texture of the meatballs were softer than I like them. 

Both pasta dishes were huge and reheated well the next day for lunch.
author: Kevin L.

description:
The Papparadelle (noodles w/hot Italian sausage and squash) is heaven!! Def one of the best Italian joints I've been too. 

Make reservations and have your party arrive on time, as you can't order entrees until everyone's arrived.

Well worth fighting the Mission parking to get here!
author: Thomas N.

description:
I love Emmy's. I still miss the weirdness of their old location but the new spot is bigger and has a fun (if occasionally too loud) vibe. 

Their pasta is amazing and they make their standard spaghetti noodles and zoodles perfectly. The only thing that's missing from their menu is vegetarian meatballs. The absence of non-meat version of the classic "spaghetti and meatballs" makes this a less compelling restaurant for vegetarians and groups. But if that doesn't bother you, this is a great place for a delicious meal.
author: julie r.

description:
I was really hoping to like this spot, give how kitschy it is and the strong reviews, but it fell short. The service was friendly, albeit slow. Folks that were seated about 25 minutes after us received their entrees at the exact same time. 

The real issue was the quality of the food and drinks. My partners margarita was lacking flavor, and the garlic cheesy bread was overloaded with garlic...it lacked a balance of butter, cheese and garlic.  Even worse, neither of the pasta dishes was al dente. The spaghetti with meatballs was drowning in sauce, while the pappardelle with butternut squash and spicy Italian sausage lacked flavor. I have pretty high standards having lived in NY for 12 years, where they take Italian food seriously (both Italian American as well as regional Italian), and no self respecting Italian place would have overcooked the pasta so much.
author: Dave R.

description:
So I haven't been to Emmy's Spaghetti Shack in awhile and I'm glad I came back because it's better than I remember. The menu offers much more food variety, however I highly, highly, highly recommend the spat and balls. Honestly some of the best spaghetti and meatballs I've ever had. Last night I realized they put capers in the meatballs and I think it adds a lot of flavor and dimension. (I will definitely start adding capers to the meatballs I make.) My mom had the zoodles with vegan walnut pesto and really enjoyed it. I would recommend getting an order of the zoodles and spaghetti and meatballs and mixing the two... so good! Then again I'm pregnant and like weird shit.  My husband enjoyed the soup of the night, creamy roasted red pepper, and the focaccia bread is always D licious. 

I have a big appetite but I would really recommend splitting a portion of spaghetti and meatballs. The spaghetti is enough to feed two and perhaps just order an extra side of meatballs. The Cesar salad tasted different than I remember and it honestly wasn't anything memorable. I do like that they now take reservations through Yelp because the wait used to be long at the prior location. Not crazy about the decor, but let's be real, I'm not coming here for ambience. And the service is great.
author: Justine D.

description: Good decent place for a dinner once in awhile but the reason I am not a fan anymore is because the prices are ridiculous and the wait staff isn't the friendliest, nothing too bad but I just don't get a good vibe here
author: Muhammad U.

description: Cool environment with funky interior decor. Food was average. I ordered the steak - came with great seasonal veggies and mashed potatoes but was well done when I ordered it medium. Service was average. The server who brought us drinks was very confused and our waiter didn't check up on us very frequently. They charge 20% gratuity for parties of 6+. I'd come back for a drink but the food was subpar.
author: Anna H.

description:
OMG!  I was thrilled to finally be able to walk into this establishment without a 1 hour wait time.  My daughter and 4 year old granddaughter were with me.  Monday and Tuesday nights children are "free" and can choose their food item off of the child's menu.  My granddaughter ordered the mac n cheese, my daughter the salad "special of the night" which had heirloom tomatoes, quinoa, avocado, fresh lime dressing and other garnishments.  The salad was divine!  She also ordered a zucchini soup.  It was creamy, delish , but packed a little bit of a punch - spicy (assuming maybe cayenne or white pepper?)

I ordered the pasta with meatballs.  They are very generous with their servings.  My granddaughter loves pasta and asked if she could have some.  I placed some pasta on a bread plate for her.  Emmy's also serves a focaccia bread that you dip in a olive oil/vinegarette.  I was able to take home pasta for another meal at home.  Upon preparing my leftover the next day I was even dipping my fork into the takeout box putting cold pasta into my mouth.  I'm sure I had garlic breath, but at this point didn't care as the pasta was absolutely delicious.  Probably better to eat here except on the weekends when you will have an hour wait time.  I want to return here again soon.  I give this place a 10 star rating.
author: Karen B.

description:
I had Emmy's on my radar after seeing the restaurant on a foodie article somewhere a few months ago about the best pasta in SF outside of North Beach. After glancing over the menu, I was excited to find a great deal of vegan dishes and ZOODLES! The perfect option when you're wanting some Italian food but don't want to carb overload.  A rainy Saturday night, my fiancé and I made it down to the mission to dig into some good 'ol Italian food at Emmy's Spaghetti Shack.  

We arrived around 8PM and were told there would be about a 30-45 minute wait for a table for two. No problem, put your name down and grad a drink next door at the Royal Cuckoo (highly recommended!) and the staff from ESS will text you when the table is ready.  After one very strong Manhattan, some good live jazz music and the wait time flew by for our table.  We were immediately sat towards the back and greeted by the server with some water.  I went for the Zoodles and my fiancé choose the famous spaghetti and meatballs.  I also got a glass of the house red wine (reasonably priced at $8 a glass).  The house wine changes frequently, and I believe it was a Grenache. A nice bold red, perfect for pairing with some Italian. 

The food came out quite fast and the portions were massive.  The spaghetti comes with three HUGE meatballs and what my fiancé said was a nice al dente pasta and perfect marinara sauce (that I saw on the menu is vegan).  The zoodles were a delicious garlic bomb. Not too oily and has some artichoke hearts mixed in, nuts, and served with some lemon that really gives it a nice zing.  ESS has a great casual Italian vibe and friendly/quick service.  Would have loved to sit out on the back patio if it were nicer out and you can even hang out and play some vintage pac mac or arcade games while waiting on your table/food.  An affordable option for damn good Italian food and worth the trip outside of North beach to check it out. Will be back soon!
author: Kelsey B.

description:
More like 2.5 for me, but 2 stars seems a little harsh.

First of all the staff was friendly and attentive, no issues there.

This review will be a little disjointed,  but I'm just going to shoot from the hip.

The meatballs were not as meaty as I hoped and were more spongy that I prefer, that might just be personal opinion, but that is my comment on the spaghetti and meatballs dish.  The pasta and sauce were good and so was the portion size.
 
The focaccia bread that they brought to go with the oil and balsamic vinegar was sub part in my opinion.  I ate all of it b/c I love bread and I was starving, but it was dry and not that good.  the oil and vinegar mix was nice though.

The Orecchiette was a dissapointment.  The pasta was good, the sauce was good, the pancetta was very good, but the brocoli rabe was horrible.  It was really bitter and sour tasting and totally overpowered the whole dish which was otherwise very good.  

It wasn't just me, but my date also said the exact same thing.  That was a huge disappointment.

$40 after tip and tax for two pasta dishes.

Side note, the place is relatively cozy, but not to the point of being romantic in my opinion.

There are pinball machines in the back as well as a photo booth in case either of those things are your thing.

You also probably want to book a reservation ahead of time.  If we didn't sit at the bar after a spot opened up, it would have been about a 40 minute wait even though I noticed two open tables (it's possible they were only open b/c of upcoming existing reservations).
author: Ty C.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite restaurants. Highly recommend for nights out. Highly do not recommend for parties. 

We went here for my wife's birthday and I made a reservation at 7 for 9 people. This place is not good for large parties. We got to Emmys at 6:55. We were not seated until 7:40. There was only one table large enough for our party and there was already a family sitting there so we had to wait for them to leave. When we finally got seated, gave us cheesy garlic bread on the house. Which was fantastic. Everything about every meal was fantastic. We had a great time. Before we got seated we asked them to chill our birthday pie. They did no problem but they charged us $3.50 for 5 people as a cakage fee so it was $17.50. The pie cost me $5. 

Anyway, whatever, the food is great. Service is okay.
author: Be L.

description:
I went with a large group.  Our waitress was friendly and made food recommendations.  

She recommended the meatballs and the zucchini pasta.  We also had garlic bread.  

I really did not like the food.  I felt that it was something that a novice could make in their house.  The spaghetti sauce tasted like something out of a can.  The meatballs didn't have the greatest flavor.  The garlic bread was something that I could have easily made at home with overwhelming amounts of butter and garlic.  

It's really not true Italian food.  I wouldn't go back unless a group wants to do.
author: Paul A.

description:
PROs
Classic spaghetti & meat balls on point: Noodles not too soft, flavorful red sauce, amazing meat balls!
Generous portions
Truffle Fries crackin'
Service is fairly quick, which I can appreciate

CONs
Felt a little too close to the tables next to us
Skip on the cheesy garlic bread (nothing special)
author: Eva H.

description:
Amazing! Emmy's Spaghetti Shack is by far one of the top places in the city if you want to enjoy a amazing plate of spaghetti! Always busy! Which means it is pretty amazing! The drinks from the bar are great starters, appetizers couldn't be better (cauliflower mozzarella is great), and the meatballs were amazing! Tried my first Underberg shot after dinner too ( definitely ask for one )
Staff is great they make you feel at home. The only thing I'm not a fan of is that a few tables up front are together where they sit two separate parties at.  I didn't ask to move, I just went with the flow because we didn't want to wait longer for a booth. But if you get a friendly table mate like we did then it all works out! Definitely try this establishment, you won't be disappointed!
author: John O.

description:
Atmosphere:
My first overall impression was that the whole restaurant itself had a unique and fun atmosphere. The walls be furniture are a mix of a thrift shop with a Spencer's store from the mall.

Food:
First off the custom menus are awesome with tiny doodles of the food. We ordered the spaghetti and meatballs ( the highlight of the meal) and the Orecchiette. Both of the dishes were on the more salty side but the orecchiette was defiantly really salty and the flavors did not mesh well. Highly recommend getting the spaghetti with meatballs along with the pear mule or the drinks they serve in the boot.

Service: 
It seems that all the waiters here are in a bbad mood. From the time we got seated to when we left it seems that smiles were rare here. I didn't mind this so much but it would have been nice to have a happy atmosphere so we can enjoy our food that much more. The only exception to this is the bartenders are friendly and seem to be in higher spirits then the rest of the staff.

Overall:
I would recommend going here and sticking with the classics. It has a fun decor with some arcade machines in the back. The bathrooms are clean and the food is exceptional.
author: Khan N.

description: Overall I had a good dinner here! I'm from Rhode Island and my maiden name ended with an i so my standards for Italian food are super high. While Emmy's was good it was nothing to write home about (although here I am writing). Major points on Yelp reservations since it made seating our large group a breeze. Our waitress was friendly and handled our largeish group pretty well. We ordered the garlic bread as an appetizer and unfortunately it came out about a minute before our entrees did. Maybe that was by design, but I always like appetizers to be done before the mains come. I went with the classic spaghetti and meatballs, mostly because I love them, secondly because the photos on Yelp looked so damn delicious. It was photogenic yes, but not the most flavorful spaghetti and meatballs I've ever had. Overall with so many great dining options in SF I don't think I'd head in again. If you don't eat much Italian food and are craving it then I think Emmy's would be a great spot for you to check out. Oh, the interior is pretty cool, tons to look at which is always fun!
author: Holly K.

description: This place is awesome! Great staff and consistently great food. My neighborhood go to spot.
author: Daniel W.

description: Great place. My family loved it. The experience was eclectic, the service is spot on family friendly and attentive, and the food was good. Spaghetti and meatballs, pork chop, focaccia bread---Prego!
author: Kerry L.

description:
Besides the huge portions and the delicious Michelada, I have to say that I LOVE this place! The sign alone deserves a 5 star rating... Too many restaurants are too accommodating to children... adults are here to enjoy their meals, not deal with people's mistakes...

Definitely worth a try if you're in the neighborhood... Good ole no BS comfort food.
author: Nathan D.

description: Great place to eat, generous portions and great atmosphere. Delicious spaghetti and delicious drinks. Very quirky place with hand written menus. Good service! I recommend you make a reservation or come with time because it can be busy.
author: Marco J.

description: IT'S SOOO GOOD!!!  First time at Emmy's and I was impressed by the staff and the food. The spaghetti and meat balls were delish!!   And I couldn't resist detest which was on point. Will be back soon
author: Eric P.

description: This place is pure hype. I have eaten here 3 times over the course of about 10 years, and it's always been pretty bad. Seriously, this is not good Italian food. Bland, flavorless meatballs and sauce.
author: Captain B.

description: Cool hip little place with food to match. You're not leaving hungry. I had to try the spaghetti and meatballs. Very good. Pasta was cooked perfectly. Not over cooked which is so easy to do. Meatballs did not disappoint. Also ordered the zucchini noodles. Surprisingly tasty. Definitely going back.
author: Dan C.

description:
Delicious! Their menu is pretty crazy, and the atmosphere is kind of divey, but has quality service and food. I came here with my coworkers, and we ordered a whole unofficial tasting menu. 

Appetizers:
- Mozzarella balls: absolutely delicious. I don't normally like mozzarella, but these were perfection, fried with the texture of a tater tot and savory. 
- shrimp ceviche: kind of out of place, and the shrimp was cooked, but it was top notch! Really refreshing and punchy with flavor. Even the from a guy who makes his own ceviche loved it. 
- garlic bread: this was alright. It was slices of toast, with pretty raw minced garlic and cilantro all over it. WARNING: this will give you garlic breath for a couple days at least. No exaggeration. 

Main dishes:
- Bucatini with mushroom and leek: this was one of my favorites. The bucatini is like a short spaghetti straw (it literally has a tunnel/hole through it!). It was really creamy, and the mushroom and leek offered it awesome mix of texture and subtle flavors.
- Fall pappardelle: this one was just okay. By the time I got to this dish, the pasta was cooled and stuck together in an unappetizing mass, and I remembered it tasting slightly bitter 
- Zoodles: SO GOOD. I am a converted zoodle fanatic now. Everything about this dish was just perfect: the texture of the zoodles themselves (slightly crunchy), the fat juicy shrimp, and whatever sauce/seasoning they had complemented everything super well. 
- spaghetti with meatballs: I know they're famous for this dish, but I think my expectations were much higher. The spaghetti was good, the meatballs fell apart, it was tasty, but it really didn't stand out.
author: Ke C.

description: Best meatballs outside of my Sicilian grandmother. And I've been searching for something close to hers for years. My heart would sing if they used mostaccioli or rigatoni instead of boring spaghetti (which I never saw growing up).
author: Carlo S.

description:
Our table was ready when we walked in the door. Service was attentive but the way they phrased some questions was odd/abrupt. 

Food was solid. I got the spaghetti and meatballs. I wasn't sure how an all beef meatball would work since most people make them with a mix of meats but these were good. The pasta looked under sauced but I really liked how they tossed it for even coverage. It was quite good and I have leftovers for lunch!

I like that they have house wine by the carafe. Made me feel like I was in Italy. 

I didn't like that the bread was in a big plastic bucket behind a table and at the exit to the kitchen. It felt too exposed to the guests and I regretted eating it after I saw that. 

The noise level is quite high but I like the ambiance. I'd go back.
author: Tera K.

description:
A group of friends (5x) came here for dinner on a Saturday night. We made a reservation online and when we arrived our table was ready for us. 

My friends swear by their classic spaghetti and meatballs but I opted for the Linguine with Clams and Chorizo. It was actually spicy! Highly recommend.

A few vegetarian specific items on the menu, nothing substantial, but when we asked the waitress she also offered regular items tweaked to remove the meat. Really helpful!

Great friendly atmosphere. Will definitely be here again sometime!
author: Ana S.

description:
So yeah, their spaghetti is good. Really good. It's quite a lot of food but if you have faith in yourself you can conquer the dish. 

The atmosphere is pretty laid back and the wait staff was attentive even though it was very busy. On a Saturday night there was an hour wait, but there are plenty of bars nearby to kill the time, of you can flag down a waitress to get a giant PBR while you wait. Or wine if you're classy.
author: Trevor B.

description: Recently celebrated a friends birthday here and it was great. The atmosphere and decorations were old school cool and funky, the apps we shared were yummy, everyone's pasta was great.  We got a pitcher of sangria for the table and everyone liked it. Would definitely go back!
author: Judy O.

description:
Solid.

Going by many previous reviews, I got lucky at Emmy's last night.

Wait time?  Zero.  We were addressed & seated immediately after walking in.  Granted it was early, around 6:00, but it was still a Saturday night.  Score.

Staff issues?  Zero.  The hostess was cool.  Our server was cool.  Score.

Pressure?  Time management?  We were not even remotely rushed.  Despite it becoming totally packed w a wait at the door long before we finished.  Score.

I went w the signature dish.  Because...when in Rome.  Good spaghetti & meatballs.  Mind blowing?  No.  But good.  The marinara sauce was subtly flavored, & just zesty enough to do its job of covering the pasta.

The meatballs were on point w texture.  They were nice & tender, while being thoroughly cooked.  The bread in them comes through though, & I prefer a meatier meatball.  No harm, no foul.

The meatball sandwich was surprisingly the superior dish.  The addition of fresh basil, provolone, & ciabatta bread elevated the meatballs & the marinara sauce to a higher level.  The basil cut out some of the sweetness in the sauce, for the better.  It just worked out so well.  Score.

All in all, Emmy's is a solid, super casual joint.  The vibe?  Italian diner.  I thought it was a cross between The Gold Spike & Sparky's.  Both of those restaurants are gone now (Sparky's maybe only temporarily), but it looks like they had a kid, & her name is Emmy's.

3 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Last time I was here was when it was around the corner! But needless to say it's still good eats... great prices and absolutely filling... huge portions! And wow those meatballs were unreal... excellent staff and good drinks, surrounded by great dive bars to get your beer on afterwards... just go don't question...
author: Reg B.

description: I'm a huge fan of Emmy's, they make - pound for pound - a pretty damn good plate of spaghetti & meatballs. A tasty marinara sauce, 3 big, fresh meatballs and a mound of perfectly cooked pasta. Put it together and you have a belly-pleasing dish! The other pastas are good as well but the meatballs are a must. Great, friendly staff and a solid sangria to boot! Be prepared to wait though as it's always busy!
author: G C.

description: If you are hungry and can eat a shit ton - come here! Portions are great and food is amazing. Place is always packed so there might be a wait - but totally worth it!!!
author: Peter S.

description: This place offers delicious HUGE portions of spaghetti, great salads, and creative sweet mixed drinks. The focaccia bread with olive oil and balsamic that comes before your meal is a great bonus. Just be warned- it's loud! Nice accommodating servers.
author: Emily B.

description: I love this place so much! It's super quant and the food is delicious. It's casual and moderately priced. I've been to lunch recently and it was very slow. Which was awesome for us. The food did come in disposable bowls with plastic cutlery, which we did not like. Otherwise, this is the pasta spot to go to in SF
author: Derik G.

description: Love Emmys! Come here at least twice a month! The atmosphere is so cute and the staff is so friendly. Everything on the menu is delicious!
author: Cathy H.

description: Super unique restaurant with interesting decor. I love how you can make reservations. Spaghetti was decent but not out of this world. If you don't feel like cooking but still want a home made meal, this is a place for you. We all had a beautiful food coma afterwards.
author: Michael H.

description:
So good. So well priced. How often do you hear that in the city?

Definitely try the Mayan Prawn Risotto. And also taste the Spaghetti alla Puttanesca.

We had the Roasted Cauliflower Mozzarella Balls to start.
author: Alex G.

description: A co-worker picked up take-out from here and said that the Caesar salad was good the last time she got it. Big, whole leaves and a nice sized salad. For $11, what I got was about 2 cups of cut up Romaine lettuce, 5 croutons and some grated Parmesan in one of those small rectangular take out containers. One of our doctors ordered the same salad and spaghetti. $17 for the same, small container of spaghetti.  Totally overpriced and very average food!!
author: Gail S.

description: Our party of 9 had a reservation. We were seated on time but told there was another large party after us so we'd need to be done in 90 min. Seemed weird to me. Our server was also the door hostess, not a good idea. Service was a problem, slow to get our drinks and they came at different times which made for a delayed toast. The same thing happened with our meals, we were each given our food over a 5 min window, that was strange too. Food was tasty, esp the ceviche and the cauliflower/cheese balls.  Environment was festive and it was super crowded. We all wished we'd gone somewhere else.
author: Karen G.

description: Not gonna lie - this place is pretty gooood! The spaghetti and meatballs are amazing. Simple yet so damn delicious. Even without the meatballs the spaghetti is amazing . The restaurant has a cool vibe to it. It's small but a super cool place. Def. check it out if you are in the area!
author: Nessa H.

description: Well.. the garlic bread was awesome.. they really had garlic on the garlic bread.. Very tasty. I loved my pasta and I will definitely be coming back for more garlic bread and the awesome peanut butter bar for dessert.
author: S C.

description:
I came here for dinner last night with a couple friends, and it was great. The wait at 9pm-ish was about 30 minutes. There isn't a ton of space to wait, so we started outside and then grabbed a cute hightop at the front before being seated.

I had already kind of eaten dinner and wasn't planning on having second dinner.... but once we were seated I couldn't say no. We started with the prawn ceviche which was yummy and appropriately sized for three people.

For entrees, I got the Mayan Prawn Risotto, and it was to die for. I saved a tiny bit for leftovers, just had it for lunch, and I want to go back for thirds, like... right now. One friend had the spaghetti and meatballs and wiped his plate clean. He said he could have eaten another bowl (portions are large, apparently he's just a big eater/it was super delicious). My other friend had the orecchiette and she also enjoyed hers, though my risotto stood out.

Decor is kind of kitchy-diner, but nicer than that makes it sound. Love the handwritten-in-markers menu. The waitresses/staff were all super friendly, with no rush or pressure. I'll be back for sure.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I am sooooo obsessed with the spaghetti and meatballs from here. The pasta is cooked perfectly al dente. Each strand of spaghetti is coated with just the right amount of sauce. And the meatballs....heavenly! I don't even like meatballs like that but these are moist...soft but not mushy...and super flavorful. 

Unless I'm going with a group, I refuse to order anything else. There's just something this dish that feels like home. When I've dined with a group, I was able to try the other items on the menu. Everything was yummy. But my go-to will always be the spaghetti and meatballs. 

My only gripe is that they never pick up the phone when calling to order out. They do have an app though but wait times tend to be long. I have the best luck just dropping in for take out and having a glass of wine while I wait!
author: Emily Y.

description:
I hadn't been to this place in several years, since before they relocated.  I remember them for their great food and generous servings, so I kept wanting to go back, especially as they are within walking distance of my place.  My friend and I finally decided to go one night about a week ago.  We knew they opened at either 5 or 5:30 PM, and we got there at about 20 after 5.  The gate was locked and there were no signs, so I looked on my phone.  Okay, 5:30, no problem. It looked like there were staff members inside eating.  They glanced at us a few times.

It was after 5:30 that we got worried when the gate stayed locked.  Around 5:50 I sauntered over to look at the menu of the restaurant next door.  Then I saw someone come out and talk to my friend.  She told me they were having a staff party and weren't opening that night.  We wondered aloud why they hadn't bothered to put a sign up, and why they took so long to tell us what was going on after seeing us standing out there for half an hour.

We ate at the Peruvian place nearby and had a great meal.  When we left, we saw that Emmy's had finally put up a sign about the staff party.  I gave them an extra star for past great experiences.
author: Robert C.

description:
I was introduced to Emmy's a couple of months ago and it was the first place I thought of when my father and I couldn't think of where to go eat. 
It's a fun, unique and upbeat restaurant. Their spaghetti is obviously fantastic but they also have a seasonal peach, mozzarella, tomato, basil and olive oil salad that is OFF THE HOOK! 
Our waitress was phenomenal and on top of her game. 
Both times that I have gone I've thoroughly enjoyed myself.
author: Camille G.

description:
We got the spaghetti+meatballs and the zoodles. The portions were large, and the food DELICIOUS! Spaghetti+meatballs were tasty and I can see why everyone raves about it. What I think needs more raving is the zoodles dish! The zoodles were refreshing, soooo flavorful, and provided a nice contrast to the heartier spaghetti+meatballs. 

The ambiance was loud and kinda hipster. Make sure to make reservations or come early enough to beat the crowd! I was there with a couple of friends and could honestly only hear the person sitting right next to me. 

Also, parking was a painnnnnn. Secret tip: We parked at the Safeway nearby and walked over (shhhh)
author: Joyce W.

description:
If you're craving a hearty pasta meal, I think this place is a winner. The Fall Pappardelle was absolutely amazing- I just wish their portions were bigger! The husband got the Spaghetti and Meatballs and that was also a crowd pleaser. They serve complimentary focaccia bread with your meal but the Garlic Cheese Bread were a great addition to the pastas so make sure to save room for that.
Service was friendly and definitely make a reservation if possible!
author: Grace L.

description:
Great staff, clean dinning area, and good food.

The food is a fair price for what you get. You get good portions but I personally think the food left a little something to be desired. Still pretty good though. I am just a spaghetti freak!

The staff asked if I would like my 2 year olds food brought out first. This allowed me to feed him first without juggling my food and his. AMAZING! I wish I had thought of it before.

There is a small parking lot a few spaces down that is usually full so don't count on it. $12 fee for the parking when we went.
author: Chris S.

description:
In previous visits, Emmy's spaghetti has always been superlative. Perfectly cooked noodles with a hard-to-find chewiness that kept me coming back. 

What happened last weekend? 
The spaghetti was overcooked!!!

I hope this isn't the "new normal" but I won't rush back to check.

C'mon, Emmy. Please fix?
author: marilyn w.

description:
Heard about this place and naturally went to check out the spaghetti. Huge portions, ended up taking at least half home. I'd say the spaghetti was good, but not great.

They cater to families and children a couple days per week, I think with service before 7p. They allow the kids to run wild and carry on, which doesn't bother me personally but I could see where it might others. Make sure to check ahead if that's a concern for you.

Very laid back ambience and service, sorta hipster and very casual - fun!
author: Ron F.
